author: axic3354
content:
I was conflicted whether I should post this, but in the end I wanted to share this thought: https://notes.ethereum.org/@axic/BJEbqX13j

It is an alternative approach, that (unfortunately) I don't think was considered during the past year. **It is certainly past the point of proposing any large changes to withdrawals, which I am not attempting to.**

In the end I think that despite having access to this incredible system, we are averse to solve problems with (*system*) EVM code (one big exception is the deposit contract).

author: ralexstokes
content: thanks for posting! ill call out that anyone can opt into this system by simply deploying such a contract and setting it as their type 0x01 withdrawal credential target execution address

author: ralexstokes
content: if such a contract were enshrined like you suggest, then it would reduce the number of write IOs to client state although the idea is to bound the number of writes from withdrawals per-block such that this overhead is negligible

author: .vbuterin
content: At the next ACD, imo it's worth discussing issuing an explicit warning that over the next few hard forks, RLP will probably be replaced with SSZ, and this will break apps that do in-EVM history merkle proofs

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ok, just thinking out loud: this is nice but the downside is that you need to invoke the contract with a txn. This means that caller needs a balance (as opposed to push). I would say that another improvement over this is that this auto-withdrawal can be executed as a normal tx, and the execution gas cost is taken from the withdrawal balance

author: sky.cactus
content: The conclusion from the previous ACD is that there isn't agreement on this path forward (moving from RLP to SSZ in the EL).  I *thought* we had consensus, but when I brought that up no one seemed to agree.  I'm not sure what changed or if I misinterpreted the previous situation, but from the last call at least I don't believe we have agreement on that path forward (sadly).
